Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will create a large database of digitized, linked census records for people living in the United States between 1850 and 1950. The project will expand the set of available links among the US censuses for these years by a factor of three, while simultaneously increasing the representation of women and minority groups in the data. The research team will also develop and use state-of-the-art handwriting recognition tools to digitize millions of census, vital statistics, and other records.The database will be used in promising research in the social, behavioral, and economic sciences that would not otherwise be possible. For example, the data will allow researchers to measure the intergenerational transmission of wealth or education, and to estimate the long-term impacts of childhood circumstances. This project will enhance the infrastructure for research and education because the new data science tools will be shared with the research community. Because the majority of the resources for this project will support graduate and undergraduate research assistants, the project will also contribute to the development of a globally competitive STEM workforce.

This project will create an infrastructure for transcribing and linking together large collections of handwritten historical documents using deep machine learning and crowdsourced human resources. Our project is informed by other initiatives that take advantage of recent advances in data science, computer vision, and machine learning to extract text from historical images, convert that text into usable data, and link the individuals in the record to other collections. Our work will complement these efforts, and we have unique advantages that will allow us to dramatically advance the frontier in this area. These advantages arise from our partnership with FamilySearch.org, the largest genealogical research organization in the world, which allows us to access the largest-ever corpus of labeled handwriting images from historical records (1 billion+). Furthermore, because the users of these genealogy platforms have themselves created millions of record links using their private information, we have access to a massive database of “true” links that can inform our data cleaning processes and act as training data to improve the machine learning algorithms that are part of our linking strategy. With these advantages, we will create a digitized, longitudinal panel of linked census records that will include each of the 217 million people who lived in the United States between 1850 and 1950. For the majority of these we will be able to link individuals across multiple censuses and across families, and we will extend this effort to other publicly available record collections. We will make the tools and training data that we create easy to access and use by other researchers and the general public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: National Bureau of Economic Research Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: NATIONAL BUREAU OF ECONOMIC RESEARCH INC

Performance_Institution.Name: National Bureau of Economic Research Inc

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary outcome of this work is the creation of the Census Tree -- the largest-ever database of digitized and linked census records for people living in the United States between 1850 and 1940. Building from information contributed by the users of an online genealogy platform, the researchers combined traditional linking methods and machine learning to create over 700 million census-to-census links. This includes 314 million links for women, who have been difficult to link in prior work because their surnames typically change with marriage, and 41 million links for Black Americans.

The Census Tree represents a major step forward in the effort to create a panel dataset that can be used to trace the lives of Americans in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Match rates for censuses ten years apart in the 20th century are over 80% for men, and range from 74% to 79% for women. For the 19th century censuses, rates are still well above 50%. The links are also highly accurate, and constitute a sample that is representative of the U.S. population.

The Census Tree dataset will enable promising scholarship in the social, behavioral, and economic sciences that would not otherwise be possible. To facilitate this, the researchers developed a web platform, censustree.org, where scholars can learn more about the data and how to use it and download the links. The Census Tree has been publicly available through this platform since the summer of 2023, and the list of papers using the data is already growing rapidly. This includes new work on the intergenerational effects of women's employment during World War I, on gender in the frontier experience, on the link between electrification and fertility, on the historical impacts of regional universities and agricultural education, on the effects of charity nurseries, on the long-term effects of family structure and parental socioeconomic status, and on the role that lynching violence played in the Great Migration.

Dozens of undergraduate and graduate students at Brigham Young University and at the University of Notre Dame contributed to the effort to build the Census Tree, and the work provided them with critical training and professional development opportunities. In addition to helping to create the Census Tree links and prepare them for public use, the research team also developed state-of-the-art handwriting recognition tools to aid in the effort to digitize millions of historical records from censuses, vital statistics, and other sources.


Last Modified: 11/27/2024
Modified by: Kasey Buckles

The Census Tree represents a major step forward in the effort to create a panel dataset that can be used to trace the lives of Americans in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Match rates for censuses ten years apart in the 20th century are over 80% for men, and range from 74% to 79% for women. For the 19th century censuses, rates are still well above 50%. The links are also highly accurate, and constitute a sample that is representative of the U.S. population. In addition to helping to create the Census Tree links and prepare them for public use, the research team also developed state-of-the-art handwriting recognition tools to aid in the effort to digitize millions of historical records from censuses, vital statistics, and other sources.
